subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] [QS-ASCII] Remaining disagreement
msgSnippet: I d like to start by comparing 33 and 35. Here are two silly example sentences that make use of these letters: 33. The outlaw s daughter softly applauded as he
messageBody:
I'd like to start by comparing 33 and 35. Here are two silly example
sentences that make use of these letters:

33. The outlaw's daughter softly applauded as he hauled water and walnuts.
35. She recoiled as the loyal boys enjoyed deploying the purloined toy coins.

Transcribing them using the current proposals (source:
'qs_keybd_proposals3.csv'):

Jerome kbd:
{33. H QtlY'z dYtar sYftlI aplYdd Az hI hYld wYtar n wYlnats.
35. S rIkqld Az H lqul bqz eGJqd daplqiN H parlqGd tq kqGz.}

QS-SAMPA:
{33. D HtlO'z dOtyr sOftli yplOdd az hi hOld wOtyr n wOlnyts.
35. S rikRld az D lRVl bRz EqJRd dyplRIN D pyrlRqd tR kRqz.}

Peter Guinness:
{33. D WtlQ'z dQtur sQftlE uplQdd az hE hQld wQtur n wQlnuts.
35. S rEkYld az D lYGl bYz eMjYd duplYiN D purlYMd tY kYMz.}

QS-B:
{33. D BtlQ'z dQtur sQftlI uplQdd az hI hQld wQtur n wQlnuts.
35. S rIkqld az D lqcl bqz eNjqd duplqiG D purlqNd tq kqNz.}

QS-Nu:
{33. D Ptlq'z dqtur sqftlI uplqdd az hI hqld wqtur n wqlnuts.
35. S rIkQld az D lQcl bQz eNjQd duplQiG D purlQNd tQ kQNz.}

Moira:
{33. D Qtly'z dytur syftlE uplydd az hE hyld wytur n wylnuts.
35. S rEkqld az D lqcl bqz eMjqd duplqiN D purlqMd tq kqMz.}

It's difficult for me to see a compelling rationale for any of the
proposals regarding 33 and 35. We each have our own memory queues, and
I like having upper case assignments for the "loop" letters. Q looks
as much like "oy" or "oi" to me as q does. For now I think I'll leave
QS-Nu as it is, but I remain open to persuasion.

Ted


On Jan 10, 2008 2:36 AM, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Based on Moira's spreadsheet, with Ted's and mine latest
> changes/corrections inserted I've created a list of the
> remaining 16 disagreements. I wasn't sure whether I should
> list absence of a mapping in Peter's proposal as a point of
> disagreement, but in the end I followed Moira's
> classification.
>
> I also made a list sorted by degree of disagreement -- easy
> to do with my text editor's sorting function -- in order to
> make the disagreements easier to quantify. It turns out that
> Ted and I agree on all but four points. (#33, #35, #37,
> #1.5) It also turns out that Moira agrees with me and Ted,
> or disagrees only in casing, on five points (#14, #17, #20,
> #36, #35), which would bring down the really contentious
> points to eleven.
>
> Listed alphabetically:
>
> | QS # Name Jerome Peter QS-B QS-Nu Moira
> | #14 J'ai Z Z J J J *
> | #17 Ye j y y y Y *
> | #20 Why ` P W W W *
> | #21 Ing N N G G N **
> | #27 Eat I E I I E **
> | #29 Eight E A E E A **
> | #31 I F I Y Y I **
> | #32 Ah y R A A P ***
> | #33 Awe Y Q Q q y ***
> | #35 Oy q Y q Q q ***
> | #37 Out Q W B P Q ***
> | #23 Noon G M N N M **
> | #36 Up u G c c c *
> | #1.5 half-p ] P B B *
> | #17.5 half-y ^ ^ ^ G *
> | #18.5 half-w @ M M @ *
>
> Sorted by degree of disagreement:
>
> | QS # Name Jerome Peter QS-B QS-Nu Moira
> | #14 J'ai Z Z J J J *
> | #17 Ye j y y y Y *
> | #20 Why ` P W W W *
> | #17.5 half-y ^ ^ ^ G *
> | #1.5 half-p ] P B B *
> | #36 Up u G c c c *
> | #18.5 half-w @ M M @ *
> | #31 I F I Y Y I **
> | #21 Ing N N G G N **
> | #27 Eat I E I I E **
> | #29 Eight E A E E A **
> | #23 Noon G M N N M **
> | #32 Ah y R A A P ***
> | #37 Out Q W B P Q ***
> | #35 Oy q Y q Q q ***
> | #33 Awe Y Q Q q y ***
>
> I suggest that Ted and I proceed to list our arguments for
> our choices on the points where we disagree, and then
> discuss how we can reach agreement on a QS-NB (seeing how
> QS-Noob may not be a very good naming choice! :-)
>
> So here goes:
>
> * #1.5 half-p P *
> 1. The one big pro-argument is obvious: the half-letter
> maps to the upper-case of the letter whose lower- case
> the full-letter maps to.
>
> * #33 Awe Q ***
> 1. Uppercase Q looks similar to uppercase O, making
> spellings like {nQrT, fQt} 'north, fought' easier to
> read in ASCII.
> 2. The Q key lies between the A key and the W key, AW
> being a common TO spelling for #33.
> 3. "Quarter" sort of works as a memory cue.
>
> * #35 Oy q ***
> 1. Lowercase q is visually similar to oy, or to oi with
> the i lengthened downwards.
> 2. The words "quoin" {kqn} and "quoit" {kqt} -- the only
> ones beginning with "quoi-" in both LPD and my English-
> Swedish dictionary -- work as memory cues.
> 3. The Unicode letter U+01A3 LATIN SMALL LETTER OI = LATIN
> SMALL LETTER GHA is really a German script q! (A minor
> one, but it works for me! :-)
>
> * #37 Out B ***
> 1. The memory cue "Bout", which is B + the QM name of
> the letter.
> 2. B resembles U+0222 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER OU, and OU is
> the usual TO spelling for #37.
> - This mapping is really the odd man out in QS-B, but I
> guess there has to be some such.
>
> /BP 8^)>
> --
> Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> No man forgets his original trade: the rights of
> nations and of kings sink into questions of grammar,
> if grammarians discuss them.
> -Dr. Samuel Johnson (1707 - 1784)
>
>
